Speaker: written by
Dialogue: Frank Fenton & Winston Miller

Speaker: stickman
Dialogue: Eight the hard way! Pay the line!

Speaker: stickman
Dialogue: Seven a winner.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, thanks...

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Know him?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: No. Why?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: He just seems kind of free with that money.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Whiskey -- like you'd pour it for yourself.

Speaker: blonde
Dialogue: Don't you know it's no fun to drink alone?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Not till after the first one.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: You a stranger here?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What kind of whiskey was that?

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: On the bottle it says Rye -- but the way you take it, I don't see what difference it makes.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Another Rye.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: You didn't answer my question.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm a stranger everywhere.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Got a job?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Listen, soldier. I know that one, too. Got a job, stranger? No? Why don't you join the Army? Three meals a day, a place to sleep, a nice warm uniform --

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: It has a little more than that.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's got Second-Lieutenants.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: If you want to make it a personal matter --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't make it anything, soldier. You tried to sell something and I didn't buy it -- so why don't you just beat it?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: If I weren't in uniform, I might teach you some manners.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If you could teach me anything, you wouldn't be in a uniform.

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: You couldn't be looking for trouble, could you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I could, but I'm not.

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: That's fine, because this is one of the best places West of the Atlantic Ocean to find it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That was my first impression.

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: That Lieutenant's a nice young boy.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't doubt it, but his mouth is too big -- like your ears.

Speaker: blonde
Dialogue: How is it now?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: blonde
Dialogue: Drinking alone?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's all right -- try it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's not a good habit if it makes you pick fights.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only with Second Lieutenants.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: We like Second Lieutenants here.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You see -- here everybody fights, except the Army.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I wouldn't know --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: So anyone who doesn't like the Army --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I know what you mean, but I'm afraid I'll have to come back. I like the way you sing.

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: Okay, Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's his limit.

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: There's a sucker getting hot with the dice at Ed's table.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Well -- cool him off.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Captain Iles -- the Commanding Officer of the Post.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Mr. Haven -- sir.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I see you finally got here.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I seem to finally get everywhere.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Mrs. Caslon, -- Mr. Haven.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: You've met Mr. Stellman.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: It came off beautifully. He picks a very good fight. In fact, I think I'm still a little sore at him.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Sit down, Mr. Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thank you, Captain.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: So you're operating under sealed orders.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: All this mumbo jumbo is characteristic of the Military Information Department.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: We use it as sparingly as possible.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I've been in this territory for a number of years -- and I think it might be a little rougher here than a suburb of Washington, D.C.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Very possibly.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Then why is M.I.D. sending you out here?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Because two soldiers have been murdered.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And they think I can't handle that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: They merely know you haven't.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I have only ninety-four men on the post, with Indian trouble up north. The War Department has refused to send reinforcements, or am I boring you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm not the War Department.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: The two soldiers were killed while escorting one of the gold stages.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Is escorting gold a function of your command?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Young man, the functions of my command look very pretty on paper, but they're not very practical in a territory like this. Do you have any illusions about that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I have no illusions about anything.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What's happening to the gold?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I've permitted it to be stored in a warehouse on the post. Now everybody is waiting to see what I do next.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What do you do next?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Aren't you here to tell me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Wells Fargo won't convoy gold. You tried and failed and two men are dead. The gold is piling up on the post and you can't move it. Your post is under-manned. You want the Quartermaster at Platte to replace seventy uniforms sent to the freight office at West Rim City --

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: The freight building burned down with the uniforms! I'm not operating a fire department -- and if I was, West Rim City is sixty miles away!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That doesn't concern me either.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: What does?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The killing of two soldiers.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: They were my men, Haven, and I'm trying every way I know to find out who murdered them.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: So will I.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: You'll find it harder than you think. I don't know how you operate, but it's a dangerous job that can get you killed.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Perhaps I can get some help from the Sheriff.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: You can forget him. He's a miserable man that somebody is using to keep the law a joke.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You make it sound very difficult. Why don't you just wrap up your flag and take it back East with you?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Tell me, how will I know what you're doing?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll let you know from time to time.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: That's very obliging of you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: But I don't want to visit the Army post.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Then report to me through Mrs. Caslon here. You can be a friend of her husband's. He owned the Argus mine and died last year. If that meets your approval.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only if it meets with hers.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mary.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: He's a man who can sure keep a secret.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only if you have some too.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What mine did the two soldiers try to convoy the gold from?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That brings me to a question I decided not to ask.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can understand that.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I do now.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How much.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who is doing all this?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I might find out.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's why I'm here.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Don't worry about it. Trouble and I are old enemies. We understand each other.  Goodnight.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You didn't tell me your husband's name.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Ben.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Evenin' stranger.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You must know everybody in town.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Everybody but one. I don't know you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What's your name? You seem to be a pretty clever fellow.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Orville Weekly, and I can't be a total blank. I been here six years and I ain't dead yet.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Have you got a vacant room?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Day, week, month?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't always know. And the way you talk a man couldn't be very sure.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Then it's eight bucks, cash in advance.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: From Arizona, huh?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No -- I always put down where I'm going next -- so I won't forget.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Room ten -- end of the hall. Make your own bed. Furnish your own towels. Your bag's over there.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thanks a lot for the key. I'll be back later.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How about eating alone? Is that a bad habit too?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Just when you have to pay for it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's only money.  I've changed my mind since I left here awhile ago. I don't want to pick a fight -- or break the bank -- or --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What changed your mind?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's what I came back to find out.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Maybe it would be better if you found another girl.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, it wouldn't... I looked.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That man in ape's clothing -- could he be Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: His eyes follow you around like a couple of flies.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: They follow me to see that strangers don't annoy me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only strangers?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No one else would be so foolish.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: First, you're beautiful. Then I like the way you sing -- and now you're a woman of mystery.  Champagne?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't want to be a stranger, so I'll have to be foolish.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You like to take chances, don't you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If I feel lucky.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Then I'd advise you to try the dice table.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'd rather get lucky here.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Every man has a right to go to his own funeral.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I could be your cousin from Waxahatchio. I could be cousin John, a missionary on his way to China.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: He seems to be a lot of man.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: The most in town.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's a very small town.  You could get it all in this saloon.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: We usually do.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: So Charlie probably runs the town.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Why do you care?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm going to spend some time here. I want to know who winds the clock.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's been a nice conversation. I hate to have it end.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: Who's this?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Mick -- this is -- cousin John.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: From Waxahatchie.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: What's keeping him?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I think he's wondering if he couldn't do more good here.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: You aren't very friendly, are you, mister?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: A friend to all is a friend to none.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: You ought to learn not to pick 'em so easy, like you do your cousins.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Ask her?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I never saw him before in my life.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: You're too little to make that big a mistake.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You want to correct me or just bleed at the mouth?

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: Bring him outside.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: A misunderstanding.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Did you find out what he wants?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But you never know -- and the least I can do is bury him.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Mick will kill him.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's ten to one.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I don't like the other fellow's chances, but I'm a sucker for odds.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You should always bet on a champion. Then you can only lose once.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: You give ten to one...?  I'll take it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You're down. A thousand to a hundred.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Don't miss so much. You'll got tired.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: He can fight a little.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: A little won't be enough.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: Stand still and fight.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: You can't do this.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: Nobody can do this... to me.

Speaker: bouncer
Dialogue: Somebody just did.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I can't believe it. Mick Marion losing a fight and me winning a thousand!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Give it to him, Prince -- in chips.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Have some coffee?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: They told me who was fightin'. I was getting ready to rent your room. Cream or sugar?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Cream.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Myself, I'd rather fight a forest fire.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: So would I...

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: How do you feel?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Like a million dollars.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You just cost me a thousand. You lost your pipe in the fight. I brought it to you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Do you always get sweet with the men who fight over you?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Only the winners.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Tell me something --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where do you bury the losers?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You talk too much.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What do you want -- the next dance?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I think you'd better sit this one out.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Have some coffee?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The way you run this dump I knew you must be good at something else.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Some call me the town poet -- and some the village idiot. Who am I to question either? How you feel today?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Like I crawled here from Kansas City.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Well, it figures to make you pretty famous. Fact, people been askin' for you already.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: That gold mine lady -- Mrs. Caslon.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's nice.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Couldn't do better. And Charlie.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Charlie?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: No. less.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You seem impressed.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Why not? Charlie owns a piece of everything, includin' the undertaker and the sheriff.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The stage line too?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Everything but the Wednesday Bible Class. Even owns a piece of me.  Takes your money while you're here, and makes you pay to leave.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: When you get the next verse I'd like to hear it.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Can't find no word to rhyme with Mick Marion.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Carrion.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Of all the stupid bonehead plays! What did he fight about -- don't tell me a woman?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: That's what they tell me.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Who started it?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: I don't know, but Haven finished it.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: That probably strikes you as a very admirable thing.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Well, I don't think so! I have men who can use their fists. Why didn't they send a man who could use his brains!

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Well -- open it up!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Hello, Mrs. Caslon.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Captain... Lieutenant...

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Mr. Haven, we may not have very much around here that pleases you, but we do have a strict post regulation against brawling in the town. Now would you like to explain what happened last night?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I came here to return Mrs. Caslon's call.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: This book I have in my hand is the

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I am now going to read from it.  "Haven, John Martin, born Ohio 1852. Appointed Second Lieutenant. Promoted First Lieutenant 20th Infantry, March 1880; reduced in rank to 2nd

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Is that correct?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's the Army Register.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Haven, you've lost your rank once. It may very well happen again.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: To almost anybody.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Even a bad reason would delight me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What would you like to know?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Did you pick that fight?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Those things can become very vague.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And where do you expect all this to get you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That is a question I prefer not to answer.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I think you're trying to carry your authority too far.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Perhaps, but there's one thing, Captain Iles... We had an arrangement that we wouldn't meet -- you and I -- except through Mrs. Caslon... I think it's important to keep it that way...  And I like it better.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Doesn't he ever stop playing?

Speaker: ernie
Dialogue: Sam? It don't bother him. He's deaf.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where do I find the boss?

Speaker: ernie
Dialogue: First door top of the stairs.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mick been around?

Speaker: ernie
Dialogue: He's undisposed.

Speaker: prince's voice
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You wanted to see me?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: They said Charlie --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You're Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's right.  This is Prince. Don't ever gamble with him.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You mean with his equipment?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: She means either.  See you later, Charlie.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You surround yourself with very affable characters.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It makes me feel at home.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You're not that sinister. Last night with the wet towels you were Florence Nightingale in silk stockings.  Have you got a match?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: There's one in my pocket but I hate to reach for it... thanks.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Sit there.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Now you're Florence Nightingale again.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Why did you pick that fight?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I thought you did.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You could have insisted I was your cousin.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Perhaps that isn't the way I felt about you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Ouch!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where did you get the name of Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It was my father's. My name is Charlene, but --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I like that better... Charlene...  This'll be the first time I ever worked for a woman.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What makes you think you're going to work for me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You sent for me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Beautiful.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: All right, I sent for you. I was doing a nice quiet business. That was because everybody was afraid of Mick. Now every time a man has enough drinks in him to feel rugged he'll try to do what you did.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I wouldn't.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But they will.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's not the job I want. I don't intend to start at the bottom. I've been there. It's too crowded.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Where do you want to start?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: With the money.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And what will you do for it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Anything -- except hang. How did you get -- all this?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I learned one thing from my father. As long as men think they can beat the tables, all you have to do is get a table. Sometimes they run out of cash and I find myself with new responsibilities.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Such as --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: A couple of stores for one thing.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can't see myself behind a counter.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: A sawmill, and a logging camp. The logging camp's a long way from town.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I own the stage line from here to West Rim City, but that's a dud.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Outlaws. The money was in gold shipments. Now the mines won't ship it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll take that job.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You mean ride shot-gun?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I mean run the line.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Don't force your luck. You won a fight last night. You could lose one tonight.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Today I'd hate to tangle with a butterfly.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What do you think you'll get out of running the stage line?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: A commission on all the gold I get through.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That should buy you a small beer.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Glad to get it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's pretty dangerous. Even Wells Fargo locked up their station and quit trying.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who steals the gold?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Who doesn't? All they have to do is put a mask on and they all look like Black Bart.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Give me a letter of authorization.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I can't bet against you twice, can I?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You know I forgot to ask you one thing.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm working for you now. You can ask me anything.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: How do I know I can trust you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You don't.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Can I?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only with money.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Okay, boss?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Are you the manager?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: My name's Haven.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I've heard about you. You're the fellah who took Mick Marion apart.  What business you got with me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm the new boss.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Wait a minute. You're not fired.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I got to be. There ain't enough work around here for one man, let alone two.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Two can loaf as easy as one.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Mr. Leonard!

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Talk to him. He just took the reins.  This is Jim Goddard. He's a regular stage driver. Jerry here runs freight to the sawmill. Boys, your new boss.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Hello, boys.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I gotta start out of here for the sawmill before daybreak. Is that all right, Mr. Haven?

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I seen that fight last night. It was sure a beauty.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Glad you enjoyed it.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: What I liked was the way you --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Let's not talk about it. Right now it hurts my hands to listen.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What happened to you?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: My last run. I stopped a bullet.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Did you get a look at them?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: I wish I had.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think I'm going to need you and not on one leg. So sit down and give it a rest.

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm coming back later and sit behind your desk. I'll need the keys.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Only things here that work.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Son, I waste my time. I might as well waste some advice. You're full of blood and vinegar, but this whole thing has got something wrong with it. Goddard only got nicked in the shin. You might not be so lucky...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I might depend on something besides luck.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Like for instance?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Well the fact that they don't seem to shoot too straight.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: They don't need to when they shoot so often.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Worry it over.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: colored boy
Dialogue: Sumpin', ain't it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who's it for?

Speaker: colored boy
Dialogue: Miss Charlie, Mr. Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where do you drive her?

Speaker: colored boy
Dialogue: Same places. Around the hills, down the river, every afternoon.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think I'll give you this afternoon off.

Speaker: colored boy
Dialogue: I shouldn't let you do this, suh...  But ah am.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Does this Haven move me out? Is that the plan?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Prince, you know I wouldn't part with you.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: But I always come up empty.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Not quite empty. I gave you what is probably the one honest feeling you ever had in your life.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I keep forgetting that. Pardon me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What's the matter, Prince?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I don't like John Haven or anything about him.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You've said that.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: What do you know about him?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You want me to have him looked up in the Social Register?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: A man walks in out of nowhere --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And went against your table. Did he play like a gambler?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: He knew something.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Yes -- and he took Mick.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: So he can fight.  You like that part, don't you?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I'll tell you one thing, Prince, I don't like this part.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Stand there a second.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Every time I see you, you look different, but you always look beautiful. Why is that?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I always have somebody to lie to me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Take my hand --  But don't squeeze it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Tell me what you're doing with my buggy.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: My work. I'm the new transportation boss. You hired me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I presume you're going shopping?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I wouldn't wear anything sold this side of Chicago. I'm going to call on a gentleman.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: At this hour?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: His name is Mark Bristow -- and any hour, it would be strictly business.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The way you say it -- he may need a lawyer.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: He's a lawyer himself, but it won't help him.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What good is a lawyer if he never gets in a court?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Like a doctor in a graveyard. Where is this unlucky man?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Across the street.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Shall I take the horses back and rub them down?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Do you think they've gone far enough?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I haven't.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Then maybe you better wait and come with me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I wonder if you'd do me a favor?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's a big favor, and I wouldn't blame you if you refused.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I want to haul some gold from your mine.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I know it seems impossible to you, but that's one reason why I'm here -- to find cut what makes it impossible.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's why I couldn't go to anyone but you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You know what he'd say.  He'd advise against it -- but if it works my way, it may clear everything up -- for all of us -- and for Iles too. The War Department doesn't like all that gold around an Army Post.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: We're working too much in the dark. This may be the only way to see something. It's a risk -- but someone has to take it...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Just us. That'll be all who know -- and that's the idea.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Don't look so grim. It's only your gold and my skin. And smile when you walk away as though we'd been talking about what a dry summer it's been.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: ...You know I'll always cooperate -- as much as possible. But I haven't the money.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: These are I.O.U.s for gambling. They add up to six thousand dollars. Do you want to count them?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Your credit's over, Mark.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: My luck can turn, can't it?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Not on my tables.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I've seen other people fall in this trap -- but I didn't think it would get me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Nobody does. I'll have Prince drop in and go over your books. Maybe we can work something out.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: But I told you --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's the way it is, Mark. I pay off on the line and I expect to get paid. Give it some thought.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You know, you remind me a little -- back there -- of a character I once read in a book.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I had an idea you'd read a book. What was the character?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Simon Legree.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Mark is mixed up. He's either crooked without being smart, or honest without being lucky. And that's no good.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't think I'd want to owe you money -- even if I was honest.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Even?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: When I was seven I robbed my own piggy bank.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's hard to imagine you being seven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I was very fat and ate a lot of candy.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Is that why you robbed your bank?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No... I robbed it to run away from home.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Did you do it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yeah, but I had to go back.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It got dark.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: This is my favorite place in the world... I always come here to think about it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: The rook here and the stream. The stream is always running away and the rock is always watching it go. It's two ways to be -- and I always wonder which is the best.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: They probably envy each other.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Do you suppose any woman could envy me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I know it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But not a good woman?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Nobody is any good. You mean respectable.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Respectable people are very useful -- but they bore me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: With certain exceptions.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Like who?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Like Mary Caslon...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I thought we might get to that.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: How did you happen to know her?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I knew her husband.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's curious, considering --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Considering what?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Ben Caslon was a very upright citizen.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Meaning I'm not?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: -- also very respectable.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Then why would she be interested in me?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Because you're no good. And good women like men who are bad for them.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Flattery will get you nowhere.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Fooling with her will get you nowhere too -- except in trouble.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: With whom?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: The army. Why is it you're always getting mixed up with the army?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What are the odds I hit the leaf?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Four to one.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Pass --  What's the army got to do with Mrs. Caslon?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: She's engaged to Captain Iles.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Iles?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: He's the army boss here.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If you're going to frighten me, the least you can do is hold my hand.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This is where you ought to slip -- and I should catch you and kiss you.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No chance.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You finish that song?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Never do.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: It's my fatality. I never finish nothin'.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Maybe it's just as well.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Maybe so. I thought I'd tell you. Goin' back to your room will be a waste of time.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It will?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: I don't know what happened on that buggy ride, but somebody came and took all your truck.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And, naturally, you didn't do anything about it?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: What could I do?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You could have called the sheriff.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Set a thief to catch a thief, eh?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I paid my rent and I think I'm entitled to know who stole my clothes.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: A man couldn't ask for no prettier thief.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Hello... I've been wondering where you were.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I lost my shirt.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You didn't imagine that I'd let you live in that hotel, did you? I want you available -- in case of trouble.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where did I move?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: In a very nice room upstairs.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: When can you get my things back to the hotel, Charlie?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Why don't you take them yourself?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Because that's not how they got here.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You're really hard -- aren't you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You have to play everything alone?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This hotel is no good. The service is bad. The clerk's a poet, and the mattress is not quite as soft as a marble slab. But I'm beginning to like it... and if I open this window, and hear you singing...

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Is that the way you want it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's the way.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: They'll be there.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What brings you here?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: I had a dream.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: That you'd be back here tonight.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Maybe because you took the keys.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Don't they go with the job?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: You know how it is with dreams. I got the crazy idea you were going to try something --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How crazy?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Like running a shipment.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Then what happened?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: I wanted to be some help with it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: All right -- you've been some help. Now you can go back to sleep and I'll finish the dream for you.

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: I'm riding with you, Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You are?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: I'm riding.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You got more than your leg hurt, didn't you?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Maybe I just like to ride in the moonlight if nothing happens.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And if it does?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Then I think I got a little better right than you to be there.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I was just thinking -- a nice guy like you probably has a nice girl somewhere -- or a wife.

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: What are we gonna do -- have a little chat about women?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Some other time -- Let's go -- out the back gate.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What makes you so anxious to take this chance?

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: What makes you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm on commission. With me it's a matter of money.

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: And you think it's something else with me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can't think of anything else -- except curiosity.

Speaker: goddard
Dialogue: Some moonlight after all...

Speaker: bandit
Dialogue: All right -- stretch!

Speaker: second bandit
Dialogue: Pile out with the hands up.

Speaker: first bandit
Dialogue: Get down.

Speaker: first bandit
Dialogue: Turn around and keep 'em high.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Take it easy. They hang you just the same.

Speaker: second bandit
Dialogue: You, Goddard, start walking.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who sent you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You're a goner, brother -- you can talk.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Where's Joe?  Something's gone wrong, Pete.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I know one thing. He was born on a horse and he didn't just fall off this one... go and take a look.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Hello there, Mr. Haven!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Hello, Jerry. What's the haul?

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: This is that load of grub for the sawmill.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Want to ride my horse back to town?

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: What about the wagon here?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll finish the haul.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: You're the boss.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Any excitement in town?

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Don't know, Mr. Haven. I left before daybreak.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Take him easy. He's tired.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I'll give him a good rubdown.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Hey, you!

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You see a rider comin' up?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Haven't even seen a lizard. Where do I put this stuff?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Where did you put it before?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I never did. I'm a new driver. I think it's grub.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Take it to the cook shack.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You the cook?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Nah. I just wear this hat to keep the flies out of my hair.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It don't matter to me, brother. I just haul this grub. I'd just as soon haul it back.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Take it next door.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Any luck?

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: No sign of Joe. But there's the tracks of another horse, circling the mill and coming back on the road just north.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: That's bad.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Let's go and look at this guy again.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You --

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You sure you didn't see no rider?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Look -- you want me to say I saw a rider? I'll say it. I'll say I saw a ghost. It don't make any difference to me.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: When did you get this job?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yesterday.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's the system. If I don't work I don't eat. I never been able to find any way to beat it.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Who hired you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mr. Haven.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: The guy that had the fight?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Same fellow.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Friend of yours?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: This Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Any man who gives me a job is my friend. Look, I'm working, I haul this stuff out here. Nobody wants to tell me where to dump it. Everybody wants to know what I'm doin' and what I haven't seen. I don't know. I get thirty cents an hour. How smart does that have to make me?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Don't get hot.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I ain't hot. I'm just mixed up.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Forget it. I got a load for you to take back when you're done here.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: How soon?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Well, I haven't eaten anything but dust since sun-up.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All right -- grab it quick.  Work on this stuff.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: We risk him, that's all.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: He don't look right to me.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He don't look any worse than the rest of it looks right now.  Come on, get this junk out.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How about a handout?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Help yourself.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You cook pretty good.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: I ought to. I used to cook for six hundred men a day.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where was that?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Leavenworth.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This used to be my mother's special dish. She made it right out of the world.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: My old woman couldn't boil a potato.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who's boss around here?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I mean the whole works.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: You talked to the man when you came in.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Real tough-looking fellah.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: They're all tough till they get to Mick Marion.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mick come out here?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Last night -- and he looked like somebody got to him.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Face all beat up --  Like your knuckles.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I had bad luck with a crate of cauliflower.

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: That's what he brought down here -- a cauliflower face.  You fight him?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mick? Do I look like I would?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: Just the knuckles.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Hurry it up, driver!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Comin'.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Not many of the hands here, are there?

Speaker: cook
Dialogue: All up at the logging camp.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Much obliged. That was real fine mulligan.

Speaker: ben
Dialogue: Maybe this isn't such a good idea.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Who said it was? I just want that gold outa here the easiest and quickest way.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You see this box?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: It goes to Prince. Know who Prince is?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He runs things for Charlie. Know who Charlie is?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: One thing...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: That's a gear box you're hauling back and it's got to be repaired. And you tell Charlie that if it ain't repaired we might have to shut down quick. You got that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I got it.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All right -- then get out of here!

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Well -- what have you found out?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Goddard's body -- shot in the back.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And no sign of Haven?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: One horse was missing. They might have taken him away on that. They wouldn't kidnap him if they'd killed him.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Why would they kill Goddard?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: He was a Wells Fargo Detective.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I see... he was a man they couldn't handle, so they shot him. But Haven wasn't killed.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: He may have followed them on the missing horse.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And he may be fishing for trout in the Verde River. Why do I always learn everything last? Why must everything be common gossip by the time it reaches me?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: I don't know, sir.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Neither do I, but I'll find out. The Army didn't banish me out here to set up a listening post. Bring the man in, dead or alive. If he's alive, arrest him.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: But can you arrest him?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: No, but I can take any living human being into custody -- or am I mistaken in this too?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Then go and do it!

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Draw those blinds, Bristow.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: All right -- light it up.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Can't you put that firearm away.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can -- but it quiets my nerves.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Drink?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: We'd given you up for dead -- we --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Why, everybody. They found Goddard's boy -- didn't you know that? What happened? Tell me about it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm glad you got your voice back.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: If you're trying to imply that you frightened me, coming here like this, you're right. I'm neither a hero nor a fool.  They killed Goddard -- Why didn't they kill you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Somebody must have wanted me saved.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe a rainy day.  Only it might never rain.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: And what do you want from me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm going to make a statement, which you will write and notarize.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yes -- except that you put it away where it can't be stolen or tampered with.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I have a safe --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can see you have.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Meaning you don't trust me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I do -- but I don't think you trust yourself.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Where do you want it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mrs. Caslon has a safe -- a nice fat one.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I think I can arrange it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: All right -- here's the statement.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I solemnly swear that on Thursday last, about eleven p.m. the stagecoach in which I was riding was held up by five armed bandits. The gold I was hauling was stolen and James Goddard, the guard, was murdered in cold blood.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I trailed the bandits, caught up with one and -- killed him.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Put it down.  I then followed the horses bearing the gold to a sawmill --

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: You sure it was Haven you met?

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Don't I know my own boss?

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: Go in and get a beer.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: ...After I left there, I opened the crate. The gold was in it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Not quite.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What did you do about the gold?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I came to the conclusion that I finally had enough money to need a lawyer.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Have you seen the sheriff?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I've heard about him, and I still came to you.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I see. Well, as a lawyer, my advice would be --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I didn't come here for advice.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I'm wondering what you get out of this.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It makes me more valuable to somebody alive than dead.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't know... yet.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Now I'm wondering what I get out of it.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: They been here lookin' for you, the men.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I thought they might.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: I told them you was out.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I was. I just came in the back way.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You finish that song?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: I had her finished, but what good is it? It was about your death.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Keep it a couple of days -- may be you can still use it.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Good evening, Captain.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Any news about Haven in town?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I just saw Haven.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Alive?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Very much.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Good evening, Mary.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I just passed Bristow.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I heard it -- last, as usual.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: It was?  Yours!

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I am very calm, and I calmly ask you how you could allow that scoundrel to transport gold from your mine when --

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And he may be in town at this moment -- where, in fact, he is.  How you could do this without telling me --

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: MY sake?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Who do you think I represent?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: And while we're on the subject, who does Mark Bristow represent?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I know perfectly well he's a scoundrel too.  Is he also trying to help me?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Thank you, Mary.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I'd say that I lost my head if I believed that I had one.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: To whom it may concern. That's what it says here.  Well, it may concern me.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: It does.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: My business isn't jammed up enough -- so they send this harebrained demoted lieutenant pry around in it... They want to help me too.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I'm getting to deal with some hard men.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: You certainly are a careful man.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I have to be. I live a careless life.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What about the deposition?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: She has it. It's in her safe.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What do we do now?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: We call on Charlie.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: It's a dangerous play, Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What if she doesn't believe you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Then she'll have to believe you.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: That deposition could be a lie. It might not stand up in a court.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You're sure of that?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Well -- not exactly.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's it. You're a lawyer and you're not sure. Then how can she gamble on it, either?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Because she's a gambler.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, she isn't.  We're the gamblers, Mark. Lot's go.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You're under arrest!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: For the murder of James Goddard -- and robbery under arms!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I suggest that you start all over again, with this point in mind: the duty of a peace officer is to arrest the culprit of a crime -- not the victim.

Speaker: ernie
Dialogue: Rye?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: This is no good.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The bourbon is just as bad.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I don't mean that.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You want to leave?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I just don't like it.  I'm a nervous man. Something's going to happen. I can feel it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Then why don't we do something.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: We're doing something.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Waiting for something to happen.

Speaker: stickman
Dialogue: Charlie wants to see you. Upstairs.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: See?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Do I go with you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Can you make it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I see you found the difference.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Looks like a board meeting.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What's he doing with you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I thought I might need a lawyer.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I doubt it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can realize how seldom legal technicalities annoy you -- but I have one that might.  Besides, he knows all about it.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: About a gear box I failed to deliver.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I don't know anything! I merely --

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mark is right. He doesn't know anything. He just knows what I dictated to him in a deposition.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And what was that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It was just a story. About a man who got murdered, a thief who got shot, and a gear box that got lost. Probably nobody would believe it --  ...unless I got killed for it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Go downstairs, Pete. Watch the stairway.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Who else have you told?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No one. Mark I had to have. He's a witness and a notary. He makes it stick. He stands it up in court.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What keeps it from getting to a court?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: A cut.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: He's running a bluff!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I ran one on you.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You brought your lawyer. Ask him if this doesn't sound like blackmail.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: He can't think very clearly in the presence of a gun.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: But it doesn't bother you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, it doesn't.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: What you want is money.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I don't see how going to the law will get it for you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If you did see how, I'd never get there, would I?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I'm afraid not.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: So it boils down to this: we can make a deal, and all be happy together.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Not as long as you always have something on us.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Unless you also have something on me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And how would that be?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: When I deliver the gold to you.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You mean the gear box?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can even forget I looked inside. So I stole a gear box... I'm still a thief.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: What does he get?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: He gets even with you.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Have you lost your mind!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It was all right when he lost his money.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: All right... I'll give him the IOU's... when the gear box is delivered.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: You don't realize how important it is when a piece of machinery breaks down. It could close the entire sawmill.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I guess I didn't realize it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I think that's all.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You can stay.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think she was talking to me.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: You roll nice dice and you bet them jamb up, but some day you'll slip. And when you do, I'll be around to catch you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You know, I think he will.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Then you should be more careful.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The poorhouses are filled with careful men...  ...And so are the graveyards.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You've got a nice perfume.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Carnation.  I almost had to have you killed. I'd have hated it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: So would I.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I'd have missed you... too much.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And too long.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Did you ever tell a woman you loved her?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: All of them.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: How did you get away?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I was always in the doorway when I said it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You never said it to me.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Let's go over to the doorway.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I seem to always end up like this with you. I take you for granted. You like it that way. It goes with loaded dice and crimped cards and fixed wheels.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Isn't that your business.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It isn't my life.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You told me once you might be a missionary on your way to China. And that's as much as I've ever found out about you. You're working for me, but for all I know you could be working for somebody else.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Like Goddard?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think I better bring you that gold.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Don't tell me you're still recruiting?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Yes, we still want you. But this is a little different.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And how's that?

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Captain Iles has asked me to take you into custody, Haven.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You heard the man.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Best thing for you is to come along, Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's what I like -- the best thing for me.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Very friendly with everybody -- isn't he? Wells Fargo detectives, and now the Army. How far can he go?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Exactly where he's headed now -- to jail.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: The Quartermaster at Platte wants three sworn statements before he'll replace those seventy uniforms, sir.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Three sworn statements! I told him all I know. They were in the freight office at West Rim City. The building burned down.. .you sure he doesn't want me to send him the ashes too?  All right, have Stamm fix the papers.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Nice to see you alive.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Dumb luck.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: You seem to have been living quite an adventurous life.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Is that why I'm under arrest?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: That's indefinite. I wanted to talk to you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If you consult the Army Blue Book it might enable you to be more definite.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: UNLESS that officer should get himself about one-half as far out of line as you have!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: How far is that?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Right here in your own statement!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I see you did what I expected.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: You've gotten a man killed and Mrs. Caslon's gold stolen. Is that far enough?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Not quite.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I want these people arrested. This is all the evidence we need.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I need more.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: For what reason?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: For the reason I came here... to get the murderers of two soldiers -- not to save somebody's gold. That's a mistake you made. I still don't know who killed them, but I'm going to find out. And when the net is hauled in, they're all going to be in it.  That's my fish -- and you can have the minnows.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: When are you returning Mrs. Caslon's gold?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's a matter between myself and Mrs. Caslon.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I don't particularly like you -- but I see no reason why you should get yourself deliberately killed.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It won't be deliberate.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: What difference does it make how you get killed? Where does it leave me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Where does it leave me?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Understand this, Haven. You're heading for bad trouble -- and when it comes don't expect any help from me. Is that clear?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: From the beginning.

Speaker: stellman
Dialogue: Anything else, Sir?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Yes, three cigars, a pint of whiskey, and a copy of that confounded Blue Book.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What's the good word?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: For you it's not good. You're in bad trouble.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I don't know how you can know so much and move so little.  I think I'll try it myself.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Want to leave a call?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's very nice of you.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: What time?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: When you're sure everybody in town is in bed -- call me. And if anybody asks for me -- I went to jail.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Is this a hold-up?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I trailed one of the bandits here where they cached it. I couldn't haul it on horseback, so I came here with the wagon.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Some of it's true.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll try it again. I cached it here myself. I was going to turn it over to them. I wanted to buy a membership in their club. This was the initiation fee.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Well, you see, I thought it was worth it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What you're doing may get me into serious trouble.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I thought you were in jail.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I talked my way out.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You're a very glib man. You seem to talk your way out of everything.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Up to a certain point.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: A gun.  Champagne.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Are we celebrating something?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I think I should have been a missionary and gone to China after all.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Didn't you bring me something?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But you will?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: No -- just like that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's easy to explain. It's just a little hard to believe.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Make it as credible as you can.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I went to get it, and it was there. But so was somebody else.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Mrs. Caslon.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Alone?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No... she had a gun with her.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Did you have one too?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: The one she had was in her hand.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This could be that slip you mentioned.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: So this nice lady held you up and took the gold, is that it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's like saying I got robbed at Sunday school. It's no good, is it?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: No, it isn't.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I even had to walk back to town. I think that may be one of the longest walks I ever took.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: And one of the last.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Mick might have killed you, but you fought him with your fists. The sheriff had a gun but you took it away from him. Ben had a gun last night but it didn't seem to scare you. Now this genteol petticoat waves a pistol and you run for your life.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: He makes it sound very silly.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Or I make it sound like what it is: a lie!

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: My word doesn't seem very good around here.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: You've only got one thing left that's any good here - and that's some gold.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Is that all I've got?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Not quite. You've got some time. You've got two hours to get it here.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You want me to fatten you up before you kill me? Is that what you mean?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I said what I meant -- two hours.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I once knew a guy who stole a dime tip from a lunch counter and parlayed it into fifty thousand. I might try that -- but not in two hours.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You're sweet.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I've been looking for you. Where have you been?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I took a walk in the country.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Did you get it for her?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No.  Sorry.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: But that was the deal. You agreed to --

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: If you're trying to pull something --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You want to listen?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I can't deliver it because I no longer have it. It was taken away from me by Mrs. Caslon. I've told Charlie, and she's very unhappy. I have two hours to produce the loot. You haven't any idea where a man could raise fifty thousand quickly, have you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I thought not.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What are you going to do...?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Nothing, Mark. The boat just sailed.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: What about me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You'll have to think of something very good.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I can think of something.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Go ahead, Mark. Go ahead and do it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Everything ready?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All set.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Got enough men at the sawmill?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Plenty.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: All right. Go back out there and get them into the uniforms. We'll hit the post just before midnight.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I don't know what we're waiting for.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I gave him some time. He's in the hotel. He's not doing anything. I gave him some time. I don't care what he does with it.

Speaker: mick
Dialogue: And I don't care when, but I'll get him.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Again?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Bristow's here.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: This should be good.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Let him in.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You want the I.O.U's?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: You mean --

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Why? Did Haven --

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: No, he didn't.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Then I don't understand --

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: We don't think they're going to be any good.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I didn't have anything to do with it. All I did was write it. I'm not in on this. I can still make them good.  Or I can --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I can do business.  The only copy.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Let's have it.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Nothing. I just want to get out of it. I never had any part of it. This ought to prove that!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: This?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I'll go and see about this!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Sure, you see about it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Take this along.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Something left to wait for?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: mark's voice
Dialogue: It's me -- Bristow -- let me in.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You going to shoot me, Mark?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: You double crossed me, Haven.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I did?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: I got the deposition back. I took it to them.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: It wasn't there! It was a piece of blank paper!

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Don't you laugh at me! I ought to kill you!

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: They want you to, Mark.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And it may be your only out, if you do. But I doubt it. You know why? Because even if you took them my scalp, it wouldn't buy your life. You're in debt and you're broke and you're scared -- and you know far too much. There isn't any way they use you -- alive. Can you think of one?

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: They're going to do it. I know it. They're going to kill me --  Why do they have to kill me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Us, Mark...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This must be hers.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: She's sweet.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: There's one thing, Mark.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: There is?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You might get out of town.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: There isn't a chance in a thousand.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If there's one in a million, it's the only one you have.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Yes -- we might get away with it. We might...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'm not going.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I have to stay.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: But you can't stay. You said yourself --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: If you must do this, go straight to your horse. Don't stop for anything.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: -- I've got a lot of important papers --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You haven't got anything important left, Mark -- except your life, and very little time to keep it. You do it very fast and you might be lucky.

Speaker: bristow
Dialogue: Yes. I might be. I'll try it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You didn't throw away that verse?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You won't have to change it much.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: You ain't going out there with that?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Not much, is it?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: You'll never get closer to having nothin' --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No -- I won't.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Say --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yeh?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: I'm naturally sentimental, bein' a sort of poet.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Naturally.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: I keep a bunch of gimeracks -- an oldtime sheriff's gun, a bullet from a dead bandit, a rosary from some guy they hanged.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: That's nice. A hobby?

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: In a way -- Want to leave me something?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: This is all I seem to have.

Speaker: orville
Dialogue: Where's the uniform that goes with it?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What do you want for --  Yeh? A very good question.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I might even know. I think I'll try to go and find out.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: All right, you -- march.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You loaded your gun for this?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: No -- you did.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Come on, you! Keep moving!

Speaker: pete's voice
Dialogue: Where you guys goin'?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: You want them uniforms out, don't you?

Speaker: pete's voice
Dialogue: I'll tell you when.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: What you think you're doin'?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: That's all right. Just barge right in! I'm going to tell you something...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, you're not. You're going to listen.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You lost some uniforms? You thought they were burned?

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: They were.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No, they weren't, but they are now because I just set fire to them.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: They're smouldering right now in the warehouse at the sawmill, and there are about seventy men down there who were ready to wear them.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Wear them? What for?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: What other reason? To get in the post and take the gold from you.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You were taking a detachment up north on an Indian scare?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Well, that scare is a fake. A ruse. So you know where to send them now.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Look here, Lieutenant --

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Correction.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: Major?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You better get down to that sawmill, Captain. They may try it anyway.

Speaker: iles
Dialogue: I guess I owe you an apology.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll take it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only fifty thousand.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: There is. You can give me back my gun.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: And you can give this one back to the sheriff.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I always try to forget.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Not with them...

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: There's seventy men ready for any kind of play. I say we can still swing it -- and get out of town.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Can we?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: You wanted to give Haven time. Well, he took it.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You better get out before he takes you.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: By that I presume you intend to remain.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I've been here as long as I remember.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I asked you once if Haven moved me out.  I think he's moved us both out -- together.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: This is the way I wanted it... and when I've finished you will too... as though Haven had never been here.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You cause me an awful lot of trouble.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Yeh... but I finally brought you something.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You didn't really think Mark would use it, did you?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Maybe I just wanted to send you a gun.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Isn't it a little late to make any difference?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: It's pretty late.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I have to arrest you.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Murder.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I could have killed you from the window -- but I didn't. And I didn't kill the two men -- or Goodard.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Who did?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Maybe Mick -- maybe Prince -- who knows.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: You know.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You'd almost as soon be killed as arrest me, wouldn't you?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Almost.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Which are you -- Wells Fargo or Army?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Army.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I guess it's my turn to wish you'd gone to China.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I wish I had too.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: If you still have that gold, and I think you do, we might make it yet. You see I believe that every man has his price.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Some men don't believe that.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But every woman knows it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Only there wouldn't be any women on my jury.  Mick is dead for the murders and Prince can be hung for the rest of it...

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's no good...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I'll get someone --

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Tell me something...

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: This gets us all. This doesn't count.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Tell me something -- on the square.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Did you ever -- love me?

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: All the time.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Tell it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: From the first night and the first time of the song. I tried to get away from it, but every time it came back. Every time I tried to get it out of my brain I just pushed it deeper into my heart. It had to be either you or me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's all right. I love you...  Well -- say it.

Speaker: haven
Dialogue: I love you.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: See you... in China.
